title: Open6G OTIC Website
role: Open RAN Website Design and Automation Co-Op for the Institute for the Wireless Internet of Things (WIoT), a hub for developing and testing next-generation wireless networks based on Open RAN
overview: Designed a public-facing website showcasing the company’s mission, services, achievements, etc. to expand customer reach and strengthen credibility
Built a portal featuring customer and administrative views to provide a unified interface which tracks and manages the results, documentation, and resources of tests performed on customer assets

Drove the end-to-end development process of user research, branding, UI design, user testing (with companies such as NVIDIA, Keysight Technologies, and Rakuten), coding, and deployment for the website and portal
summary: During my co-op at the Institute for the Wireless Internet of Things (WIoT), I designed a public-facing website showcasing the company’s mission, services, achievements, etc. to expand customer reach and strengthen credibility. Additionally, I built a portal featuring customer and administrative views to provide a unified interface which tracks and manages the results, documentation, and resources of tests performed on customer assets. For the website and portal, I drove the end-to-end development process of user research, branding, UI design, user testing (with companies such as NVIDIA, Keysight Technologies, and Rakuten), coding, and deployment.
descriptions: The organization within the WIoT that I worked for is called the Open6G OTIC, and when I joined there wasn't much existing branding. After carefully getting an idea of what my supervisors were looking for, I created 10+ variations each of typography hierarchies and color schemes, then reached out to others in the organization for their feedback to ensure the style guide effectively reflected the Open6G OTIC's values and work.

I love putting together component libraries, especially testing multi-state elements. This step is particularly exciting to me because of how interactive it is, and it signifies I'm ready to start exploring and piecing everything together in the wireframing phase of the design process.

This isn't even a quarter of the sketches I made for the public-facing website and private client and administrative portals! I broke these projects into sections: "Home", "About Us", and "Services" for the public-facing site, client portal, and administrative portal.

In this sample of wireframes, the first are from the website, and the last two are from the portal. I made a set of low-fidelity wireframes, then a set of high-fidelity wireframes. Through extensive user-testing with people from within and outside of the organization, I gained valuable insights, such as the most intuitive workflows, the most relevant information to highlight, and the best information hierarchies. I took notes that I organized into a comprehensive affinity diagrams, then implemented their combined feedback into more iterations.

title: Kigumi Group Website
role: UI/UX Design Intern for the Kigumi Group, an Asia-based digital literacy organization
overview: Brought organization to the design process by establishing the design system with the style guide and component library
Created wireframes and redesigned the website that hosts the organization's digital literacy trainings
summary: I joined the Kigumi Group because their mission of providing a range of digital literacy trainings tailored to students in Asia really appealed to me. It’s so important for education to take cultural values into account, and a lot of their clients did not have thorough enough resources for their students. I was thrilled to help out with their website design for trainings and showcasing their organization’s work.
descriptions: After onboarding, my supervisor told me she had a functioning website quickly put together, so it lacked a design system and she was leaning towards having the entire website redesigned. I made a small adjustment to the brand color, then set the color and typography styles in Figma.

As a highly detail-oriented person, developing the component library is something that brings me a lot of joy and satisfaction. I didn’t have too many elements to make, so I created a more advanced dropdown menu. I started by setting the hover and pressed states in the prototype, then combined the elements. This dropdown will be used to switch between languages.
Based on my design discussions with my supervisor and the documentation I recorded about her preferences, I created several sketches for the home, training, and account workflows.

My supervisor and I went over my sketches, and I added comments along the way to help myself translate the designs onto Figma. Later on, the only minor tweak we made was adding some more information onto an individual training page when mocking it up.

title: Breaktime Website
role: Product Designer at Code4Community NEU designing for Breaktime, a Boston-based nonprofit organization that aims to break the homelessness cycle
overview: Designed for a timesheet-recording website used by Breaktime, a Boston-based nonprofit organization that provides young adults with the employment support they need to establish housing security
Added new features to enhance the timesheet-recording user experience so that supervisors can better serve homeless young adults by gauging their workplace performance
Updated the component library, making wireframes, and implementing client feedback
summary: At Northeastern University, the club that has continually interested me the most is Code4Community because of its mission to develop meaningful and useful products for nonprofits around Boston. I was overjoyed to join as a Product Designer and Co-Director of Events. I've had such great experiences working with my project, events, and e-board teams while developing my abilities and meeting new people!
descriptions: When I joined my project team, the previous designer had just left. There was a gap between the previous designs and working prototype at the time, so my first task was to bridge the gap through redesigning/redeclaring the style guide and component library.

After talking with my project managers, tech leads, and developers, I made the components more modernized by putting in sleeker icons and drop shadows. To make the interface less overwhelming and more organized, I made other minor tweaks such as alternating the timesheet row colors. Along the way in many design discussions, I added other features such as attendance and report/evaluation labels.

Breaktime has a form to keep track of their young adults' workplace performance, so our project team is developing a centralized online portal/space to streamline the process. Out of the 46 wireframes that I made, these are some of the primary wireframes with workflows for weekly reports and evaluations, exporting timesheets, and deleting shifts/history. For each workflow, I had several iterations. Typically, my project managers and tech leads would coordinate a design ticket of a feature to create or improve on. Then, my project managers and I would sketch out initial ideas to present to my tech leads. After that, I would replicate the design options in Figma, receive feedback from my team, and continue refining the best designs until we were satisfied. I found that clearly labeling my design workflows and leaving comments for developers on features that might need extra clarification helped the developers more effectively translate my designs through code.

title: Partnering Lab Website
role: Part-Time Research Assistant (Design) for the Partnering Lab, a Boston-based dance research organization
overview: Launched the logo and website redesign processes to more accurately reflect the dance research organization's core values through leveraging skills in identity and brand design, graphic design, and more
Created wireframes and a component library for the new website to showcase their work
summary: I took on a part-time job with the Partnering Lab because I was intrigued by their research in dance, ethics, and more along with the range of potential design tasks from the job description.
descriptions: Some of the main values that The Partnering Lab wanted to effectively communicate in their work was professionalism, complexity, dialogue, circularity and more. Starting with the colors, my managers thought gray and blue would be good neutral, polished colors for their branding.

The focus of their site was mainly on showcasing their research work, so the component library was mostly the buttons and navigation bar. I played around with cards, but made a few iterations and wanted to keep the progress, so I didn't turn it into a component.

In my first iteration, I'd been so excited to start the process of redesigning the Partnering Lab's website that I got started without having enough conversations about branding. I conducted a design review of the previous site, then started creating the wireframes. I didn't realize I used the wrong typography style - my managers told me later on that they preferred thinner text in all caps.

For my second iteration, I also didn't have the full picture, so the colors were off. I'd pulled a similar shade of purple from the previous site into this group of wireframes. However, I used a lighter shade to increase the color contrast and readability.

This time, I implemented the insights and feedback about my managers' vision for the website, which my managers appreciated. Throughout my time with the Partnering Lab, I learned a lot about the complexities of the design process, particularly how values and other design considerations should be involved.

title: RapidRoute Mobile App Prototype
role: Student in Interaction Design Principles Course at NEU
overview: Collaborated with a team to create a high-fidelity prototype of a mobile application that improves the user experience of riding the MBTA train by suggesting optimal routes based on selected preferences
Designed features that allow users to plan and save routes in advance, send users notifications about their current best options and delays, and displays nearby options with timing details
summary: For my Interaction Design Principes course, we were tasked with improving the MBTA app. I've included pages from my group's design process portfolio.
